feed.title: Data Is Plural
feed.subtitle: A weekly newsletter of useful/curious datasets.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.05.22 edition
entry.content:
Federal court dockets, Amazon purchases, Security Council resolutions, satellite-aided rescues, and protected wines.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ Data Is Plural will be taking a short break, returning to your inbox in June.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ ReaderÂ Forest Gregg used the power outage data featured in DIP 2024.04.03 to map the average days of outage per customer in 2021â€“2023 for counties in Michigan and neighboring states. Read more in Outlier Media. (Have you published something with data you found via Data Is Plural?Â Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Federal court dockets. Journalist Matt Clark has compiled a database of more than 350 million docket entries across more than 13 million cases in 180+ federal courts â€” including the majority of district, appellate, and bankruptcy courts. The records, which Clark collected through the RSS feeds that many federal courts provide, span 2013 to the near-present. Clarkâ€™s downloadable database provides information about each docket entry (time filed, entry number, description, and URL), case (number, name, type, and URL), and court. Although the database does not include the docketed documents themselves, they can be retrieved via PACER and the free RECAP archive, among other sources.

Â 

Amazon purchases. The MIT Media Labâ€™s Alex Berke et al. have compiled â€œa first-of-its-kind dataset containing detailed purchase histories from 5027 U.S. Amazon.com consumers, spanning 2018 through 2022, with more than 1.8 million purchases [â€¦] crowdsourced through an online survey and shared with participantsâ€™ informed consent.â€ The published data include â€œorder date, product code, title, price, quantity, and shipping address state,â€ and are â€œlinked to survey data with information about participantsâ€™ demographics, lifestyle, and health.â€ The researchers found that a stratified subsample of the data demonstrated â€œexpected seasonal trends and strong relationships to other public datasets.â€ [h/t Data Science Community Newsletter]

Â 

Security Council resolutions. SeÃ¡n Fobbe et al.â€™s Corpus of Resolutions: UN Security Council â€œcollects and presents for the first time in human and machine-readable form all resolutions, drafts, and meeting records of the UN Security Council, including detailed metadata, as published by the UN Digital Library and revised by the authors.â€ It covers all 2,700+ resolutions from the councilâ€™s founding in 1946 through early 2024. In addition to providing the texts all six official UN languages, the dataset includes each resolutionâ€™s title, date, council votes, related meeting number, meeting transcript, keywords, countries of focus, and more. An auxiliary dataset represents the corpusâ€™s internal citations as a directed graph. [h/t Sharon Machlis]

Â 

Satellite-aided rescues. NOAAâ€™s Search and Rescue Satellite-Aided Tracking (SARSAT) program is part of an international collaboration to locate distress beacons activated (manually or automatically) by mariners, aviators, and wilderness explorers. The agency publishes annual maps of SARSAT-enabled rescues, along with data for the most recent year-plus. NOAA has also provided Data Is Plural with data for 2016â€“2022. The maps and data files contain each rescueâ€™s date, category, description, beacon type, coordinates, and number of people saved. [h/t Dan Brady]

Â 

France and Italyâ€™s protected wines. Sebastian Candiago et al. have assembled a dataset of 5,400+ Italian and French wines granted Protected Designation of Origin status, restricting their production to specific geographies and methods. For each wine, the dataset lists its name, country, designated area, color, category, grape varieties used, maximum allowed yields, registration date, and more. Previously: Protected European ham and the EUâ€™s register of protected indications (DIP 2023.05.24).

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send tannic feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Support the newsletter and your career by becoming a DIP+ member.
entry.summary: Federal court dockets, Amazon purchases, Security Council resolutions, satellite-aided rescues, and protected wines.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.05.15 edition
entry.content:
Unaccompanied migrant children, greenhouse gas giants, 1 million ChatGPT conversations, England sewer discharge, and LA street trees.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ ReaderÂ Ian Johnson has published an exploration US federal law titles, based on Brian Libgoberâ€™s dataset featured in DIP 2024.02.28. (Have you published something with data you found via Data Is Plural?Â Click here to let me know.)

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Brad Skillman helpfully flags that, alas, the National Hospital Ambulatory Medical Care Survey (featured last week) has ceased collecting new data. Per the CDC: â€œAlthough NHAMCS is ending data collection, emergency department data collection and estimates will continue to be available [â€¦] through the National Hospital Care Survey.â€

Â 

Unaccompanied migrant children. The New York Timesâ€™ Hannah Dreier was awarded a Pulitzer Prize last week for a â€œseries of stories revealing the stunning reach of migrant child labor across the United Statesâ€”and the corporate and governmental failures that perpetuate it.â€ That reporting, Dreier has noted, was partly driven by data she obtained from the Department of Health and Human Services via a FOIA request and lawsuit. The dataset, published in December along with visualizations, describes the placement of 550,000+ unaccompanied migrant children with local sponsors between January 2015 and May 2023: each childâ€™s country of origin, gender, date of entry, and date of release to a sponsor, plus the sponsorâ€™s ZIP code and relationship to the child. Read more: â€œThe data pointed to spots I never would have thought of: Flandreau, South Dakota; Parksley, Virginia; Bozeman, Montana,â€ Dreier says.

Â 

Greenhouse gas giants. Carbon Majors, run by the UK-based InfluenceMap, â€œis a database of historical production data from 122 of the worldâ€™s largest oil, gas, coal, and cement producers.â€ It attributes to these producers 1,421 metric gigatons of CO2-equivalent emissions from 1854 through 2022. Launched last month, the database provides downloads at several levels of granularity. The least granular version indicates the emissions calculated for each entity-year combination. The most granular version breaks those emissions down by commodity produced, quantity of commodity produced, emitting activity, and reporting entity.

Â 

1 million ChatGPT conversations. The WildChat Dataset, constructed by Wenting Zhao et al., â€œis a corpus of 1 million real-world user-ChatGPT interactions, characterized by a wide range of languages and a diversity of user prompts.â€ The researchers, primarily affiliated with Cornell and the Allen Institute for AI, built it â€œby offering free access to ChatGPT and GPT-4 in exchange for consensual chat history collection.â€ Each of the 1 million rows in the dataset represents a conversation and provides its text, main language, timestamp of its conclusion, underlying model used, moderation results, inferred country, and more. [h/t Data Machina]

Â 

England sewage discharge. The UKâ€™s Environment Agency collects data from utility companies regarding sewage-discharging storm overflows in England. The records, available for 2020â€“2023, list every reported overflow event, its timing and location, number of detected discharges, discharge points, and much more. Related: Wales overflow data are available from other sources. As seen in: Maps from The Rivers Trust, Surfers Against Sewage, and The Guardian. [h/t Giuseppe Sollazzo + James Cheshire + Hugh Graham]

Â 

Los Angeles street trees. Journalist Matt Stiles has been using public records requests and official portals to compile data on 1.6 million street trees in 40+ Los Angeles County municipalities. The information varies by city but generally includes the treeâ€™s coordinates and species, often also with measurements such as height and trunk diameter. Previously: Street trees in DIP 2022.09.07, DIP 2020.11.18, DIP 2018.08.08, and DIP 2016.11.16.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send chlorophyllic feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Support the newsletter and your career by becoming a DIP+ member.
entry.summary: Unaccompanied migrant children, greenhouse gas giants, 1 million ChatGPT conversations, England sewer discharge, and LA street trees.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.05.08 edition
entry.content:
US greenhouse gas accounting, emergency room visits, global entrepreneurship, video gaming layoffs, and poisonous book bindings.

Â 

ğŸ™ Hold The Line is a bonus, crossover episode now available in the Data Is Plural podcast feed. It was created byÂ Miriam QuickÂ andÂ Duncan Geere, whoseÂ Loud Numbers podcast turns data into sound. In this episode, they have woven data on Canadian wildfires into a sonic tapestry, threaded with descriptions of the 2023 fire season byÂ Fern Yip, who spent much of it fighting to save her home and school from burning. You can alsoÂ listen to the episodeÂ in Loud Numbersâ€™ own podcast feed, andÂ read their show notes.

Â 

Â 

US greenhouse gas accounting. The Inventory of U.S. Greenhouse Gas Emissions and Sinks, published annually by the EPA, â€œprovides a comprehensive accounting of total greenhouse gas emissions for all man-made sources in the United States,â€ as well as the removal of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere attributable to â€œland use, land-use change, and forestry.â€ The reports contain a slew of data tables. Those in the latest edition, which covers 1990 through 2022, include total emissions by year and economic sector; transportation-related emissions by vehicle type and gas emitted; removals by land-use category; and more. Previously: EPAâ€™s facility-level emissions data (DIP 2023.09.20). [h/t Ben Young et al.]

Â 

Emergency room visits. The CDCâ€™s National Hospital Ambulatory Medical Care Survey, conducted annually since 1992, is based on patient records from a strategic sample of emergency department visits in â€œnoninstitutional general and short-stay hospitalsâ€. Its public, anonymized data indicate the patientâ€™s time of arrival, length of wait, and length of visit; the their demographic information, vital signs, and reasons for visiting; the hospitalâ€™s diagnoses, medications given, tests and procedures conducted; and much more. The most recent release includes 16,000+ visits that occurred in 2021. As seen in: â€œGrabbing the NHAMCS emergency room data in python,â€ a blog post by Andrew P. Wheeler. [Update, 2024.05.15: Reader Brad Skillman helpfully flags that, alas, the NHAMCS has ceased collecting new data. Per the CDC: â€œAlthough NHAMCS is ending data collection, emergency department data collection and estimates will continue to be available [â€¦] through the National Hospital Care Survey.]

Â 

Global entrepreneurship. The Global Entrepreneurship Monitor, active since 1999, considers itself â€œthe worldâ€™s foremost study of entrepreneurship.â€ A collaboration between Babson College and the London Business School, the project publishes national and response-level data from two main surveys. The Adult Population Survey, answered over the years by millions of respondents around the world, examines â€œthe characteristics, motivations and ambitions of individuals starting businesses, as well as social attitudes towards entrepreneurship.â€ The National Expert Survey, meanwhile, assesses factors such as access to financing, physical infrastructure, and government support.

Â 

Video gaming layoffs. Game Industry Layoffs, run by @dekaf, lists known staffing cuts at video game studios, publishers, and related companies. Each entry provides the companyâ€™s name, type, parent company (for subsidiaries), layoff date, estimated number of employees laid off, and source link. In 2023, the site tallied 10,000+ employees affected by 170+ layoffs; in 2024 so far, the employee count is already nearly that high, spread across ~100 layoffs. As seen in: â€œVisualizing Games Industry Layoffs,â€ by Ben Oldenburg. [h/t Vivien Serve]

Â 

Poisonous book bindings. As recently as the 1800s, green pigments containing arsenic were in fairly wide use. The Arsenical Books Database â€” part of the Winterthur Museum and the University of Delawareâ€™s Poison Book Project â€” has identified hundreds of examples of 19th-century books that used these colorants in their covers and other binding components. The database lists each bookâ€™s title, author, imprint, publication year, arsenical material, testing method, and owner. [h/t Tom Merritt Smith]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send unpoisoned feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Support the newsletter and your career by becoming a DIP+ member.
entry.summary: US greenhouse gas accounting, emergency room visits, global entrepreneurship, video gaming layoffs, and poisonous book bindings.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.05.01 edition
entry.content:
Prison commissary prices, historical markers, biological numbers, openly-licensed video transcripts, and Agatha Christieâ€™s bibliography.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ ReaderÂ Jeremy Ney has just published an edition of his American Inequality newsletter that analyzes the wiretap data featured in DIP 2019.07.03. (Have you published something with data you found via Data Is Plural?Â Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Prison commissary prices. Through a series of public records requests, reporters at The Appeal have constructed the â€œfirst national database of prison commissary lists,â€ based on documents provided by 46 states. The database contains three tables. The first links to, and provides metadata about, each list. The second summarizes each stateâ€™s prices for two dozen types of products â€” such as ramen, toothpaste, and rosary beads â€” across three categories: food, personal care/hygiene, and religious items. The third table provides 2,200+ commissary-specific prices for those products. Read more: â€œLocked In, Priced Out: How Prison Commissary Price-Gouging Preys on the Incarcerated,â€ by reporters Elizabeth Weill-Greenberg and Ethan Corey. [h/t JQ Whitcomb]

Â 

Historical markers. Launched in 2006, the Historical Marker Database â€œis an illustrated searchable online catalog of historical information viewed through the filter of [â€¦] permanent outdoor markers, monuments, and plaques.â€ The crowdsourced project has documented 195,000+ markers in the US, plus thousands more in Canada, Mexico, the UK, and elsewhere. You can browse them by location and by topic, and download data corresponding to each collection. You can also search by person, keyword, historical date, and other attributes. As seen in: â€œHistorical markers are everywhere in America. Some get history wrong,â€ by NPRâ€™s Laura Sullivan and Nick McMillan, with associated data analysis. [h/t Walt Hickey]

Â 

Biological numbers. BioNumbers wants â€œyou to find in one minute any useful molecular biology number that can be important for your research.â€ As its creators Ron Milo et al. described in 2010, those numbers â€œrange from cell sizes to metabolite concentrations, from reaction rates to generation times, from genome sizes to the number of mitochondria in a cell.â€ You can search, browse, and download more than 14,000 entries. Each includes a number and/or range, units and method of measurement, relevant organism, and source. For instance: The diameter of an e. coli cell is 1-1.1 micrometers, the lifespan of a human red blood cell is 70-140 days, and a chickenâ€™s genome has 1.05 billion base pairs.

Â 

Openly-licensed video transcripts. The YouTube-Commons dataset, built by a French startup, contains 15 million original and auto-translated audio transcripts from 2 million Creative Commonsâ€“licensed YouTube videos, sourced from 400,000+ channels. The dataset indicates each videoâ€™s YouTube ID, title, channel, and date, as well as each transcriptâ€™s original language, translated language, word count, and character count. Translations are available primarily in Dutch, English, French, German, Italian, Russian, and Spanish. [h/t Data Machina]

Â 

Agatha Christieâ€™s bibliography. Nicole Mark has compiled a dataset of Agatha Christieâ€™s published stories, covering 75 novels, 154 short stories, and 22 short story collections. The spreadsheets provide each workâ€™s title and the character-based series to which it belongs (e.g., Hercule Poirot, Miss Marple, etc.). The novel and collection entries also indicate their year of initial publication, while the short-story entries list the collections that included them.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ DIP+ members got a sneak peek of this editionâ€™s datasets on Monday, plus pointers to a few extra. You can support the newsletter and your career by becoming a member.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send mysterious feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Prison commissary prices, historical markers, biological numbers, openly-licensed video transcripts, and Agatha Christieâ€™s bibliography.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.04.24 edition
entry.content:
Public procurement, chain locations, wholesale electricity markets, food-system indicators, and 3D natural history.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ DIP+ members got a sneak peek of this editionâ€™s datasets on Monday, plus pointers to a few extra. You can support the newsletter and your career by becoming a member.

Â 

Public procurement. The Global Public Procurement Dataset provides standardized data on 72 million government contracts in 42 countries. The dataset, constructed from official sources by the Budapest-based Government Transparency Institute, represents $17 trillion in total procurement. It begins in the 2000s for most of the countries and concludes in 2021. For each contract, it provides information about the tender (title, procedure type, product code, publication date, award date, final price, currency, etc.), government buyer, biddersâ€™ names and locations, and more. The downloadable files are split into two repositories. The US, Italy, Brazil, Poland, and Colombia have the most contracts represented. Previously: The Open Contracting Partnershipâ€™s data registry (DIP 2023.03.08) and data standard (DIP 2020.02.26).

Â 

Chain locations and more. All The Places is â€œa growing set of web scrapers designed to output consistent geodata about as many places of business in the world as possible.â€ During its latest weekly run, the projectâ€™s 2,400+ open-source scrapers collected data on nearly 5 million locations. They include postal collection boxes, ATMs, various fast food chains and chain stores, gas stations, and more. The results are available on an interactive map, to download in bulk, and by location type. Related: Journalist Matt Stiles maintains a collection of US-focused scrapers gathering the locations of dozens of chain stores and restaurants, with Python notebooks for each scraper. [h/t Forest Gregg + Sharon Machlis]

Â 

Wholesale electricity markets. The US Energy Information Administration recently launched a Wholesale Electricity Market Portal, providing visualizations and downloads of market data from regional transmission organizations (RTOs) and independent system operators (ISOs) â€” the countryâ€™s electric-grid coordinating entities. The data include â€œday-aheadâ€ electricity prices, real-time prices, actual/forecasted load and demand, fuel mix by time, and local temperatures. Learn more: A 30-minute introductory video from the EIA.

Â 

Food-system indicators. The Food Systems Countdown Initiative produces â€œannual publications to measure, assess, and track the performance of global food systems toward 2030 and the conclusion of the Sustainable Development Goals.â€ As part of that work, its Food Systems Dashboard incorporates 275 metrics from dozens of sources about countriesâ€™ food availability, affordability, supply chains, safety, and related topics. Examples include protein supply per capita, number of supermarkets per capita, trans fat regulations, and food safety poll results. [h/t Jan Willem Tulp]

Â 

Three-dimensional natural history. At MorphoSource, you can â€œfind, view, and download 3D data representing the worldâ€™s natural history, cultural heritage, and scientific collections.â€ The service hosts 82,000+ 3D models you can view online; roughly half can be downloaded without prior approval. As described in a recent BioScience article, the Florida Museum of Natural Historyâ€™s openVertebrate project used MorphoSource to share 3D models and volumetric CT scans of 10,000+ amphibian, reptile, fish, bird, and mammal specimens. [h/t Duncan Geere]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send scanned feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Support the newsletter and your career by becoming a DIP+ member.
entry.summary: Public procurement, chain locations, wholesale electricity markets, food-system indicators, and 3D natural history.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.04.17 edition
entry.content:
Unregulated water contaminants, border crossings, earthquakes felt, automated decision-making in government, and aerial obstacles.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ DIP+ members got a sneak peek of this editionâ€™s datasets on Monday, plus pointers to a few extra. Support the newsletter and your career by becoming a member.

Â 

Unregulated water contaminants. Through the Unregulated Contaminant Monitoring Rule, the Environmental Protection Agency â€œcollect[s] data for contaminants that are suspected to be present in drinking water and do not have health-based standards set under the Safe Drinking Water Act.â€ The current version of the rule requires public water systems to test for lithium and 29 per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances, better known as PFAS. (Prior iterations, which go back to the early 2000s, have tested for other contaminants.) The EPA publishes the data collected, with the most detailed files listing each sample, its public water system, facility, sampling point, sample date, contaminant tested, concentration detected, and more. Related: Last week, the EPA finalized its first-ever limits for PFAS in drinking water. [h/t Lisa Sorg]

Â 

Border crossings. Michael R. Kenwick et al.â€™s Border Crossings of the World dataset â€œexplores state authority spatially by collecting information about infrastructure built where highways cross internationally recognized borders.â€ Using satellite imagery, the teamâ€™s researchers identified the locations of gates, official buildings, and split-lane inspection facilities annually from the 1990s onward. An accompanying dataset calculates a â€œborder orientationâ€ score that summarizes the â€œextent to which the State is committed to the spatial display of capacities to control the terms of penetration of its national borders.â€ [h/t Erik Gahner Larsen]

Â 

Earthquakes felt. The US Geological Surveyâ€™s Did You Feel It? initiative allows members of the public to report their ground-shaking experiences. The agencyâ€™s web pages for individual earthquakes â€” such as this page for the April 5 tremor that rattled NYC â€” feature downloadable geographic and longitudinal data that USGS has aggregated from the reports. The agency also publishes a map of annual intensities. Tip: This search lists earthquakes in 2024 that received at least 1,000 reports. [h/t Philip Bump]

Â 

Automated decision-making in government. The UK nonprofit Public Law Project last year launched the Tracking Automated Government Register, which describes automated systems that government agencies there use â€œto make or inform decisions on a range of sensitive policy areas, including how people are policed, what benefits they receive, and their immigration status.â€ It currently lists 55 systems, their names, purposes, agencies in charge, policy areas, transparency level, potential unequal impacts, and more. Last week, Western Universityâ€™s Joanna Redden and colleagues launched a version for Canada, listing 303 systems.

Â 

Aerial obstacles. The Federal Aviation Administrationâ€™s Obstacles Team â€œinvestigates and evaluates existing obstacles that may be hazardous to safe flight navigation,â€ such as tall buildings, windmills, water tanks, utility poles, amusement parks, monuments, blimps, and other structures. Its Daily Digital Obstacle File contains 580,000+ entries, which it says provides full coverage of the US and partial coverage of Canada, Mexico, the Pacific, and the Caribbean. It lists each obstacleâ€™s type, country, state, city, coordinates, height, type of lighting, and more. [h/t Michael Allen]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send tall feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Support the newsletter and your career by becoming a DIP+ member.
entry.summary: Unregulated water contaminants, border crossings, earthquakes felt, automated decision-making in government, and aerial obstacles.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.04.10 edition
entry.content:
Opioid settlement payouts, groundwater wells, work-injury laws, colonial empire timelines, and objects launched into outer space.

Â 

ğŸ”„ Last month the Caselaw Access Project, initially featured in DIP 2018.11.07, announced that the full text of all 7 million state and federal cases it has collected â€” spanning 36 million pages â€” are now freely available in bulk. (Previously, bulk data were only available for select states.) Read more: Former director Adam Ziegler on the projectâ€™s past, present, and future. [h/t Derek M. Jones]

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ DIP+ members got a sneak peek of this editionâ€™s datasets on Monday, plus pointers to a few extra. Support the newsletter and your career by becoming a member.

Â 

Opioid settlement payouts. KFF Health News has been following the slew of legal settlements by companies accused of exacerbating the opioid crisis. Last week, they published an interactive and downloadable database of payouts to state and local governments so far (and expected in the future) from the largest national settlement, â€œa $26 billion deal with four companies that will be paid out over nearly two decades.â€ The data, gathered from the court-appointed firm administering the settlement, include overall numbers for 48 states and DC, plus locality-level data for 35 states. (Los Angeles County, for instance, received $47 million in 2022 and 2023, with another $210 million expected in years to come.) Learn more: A webinar scheduled for tomorrow, in which reporter Aneri Pattani â€œwill discuss the data and how it can help you launch into coverage of the historic opioid settlement story.â€

Â 

Groundwater wells. Despite the infrastructural importance of groundwater wells, â€œa unified database collecting and standardizing information on the characteristics and locations of these wells across the United States has been lacking,â€ Chung-Yi Lin et al. write. â€œTo bridge this gap, we have created a comprehensive database of groundwater well records collected from state and federal agencies.â€ Their United States Groundwater Well Database contains ~14 million records, each indicating a well equipped for monitoring or extracting water. Where available, each row lists the wellâ€™s coordinates, county, aquifer, watershed, depth, capacity, water use category, water potability, and more. [h/t Derek M. Jones]

Â 

Work-injury laws. Nate Breznau and Felix Lanverâ€™s Global Work-Injury Policy Database tracks the history of work-injury laws (also known as workersâ€™ compensation laws) in 186 â€œindependent nation states.â€ For each, the database lists the year of its first such law, the year a law first provided insurance for work-related injuries, the type of program it established, and more. It also incorporates data on current lawsâ€™ coverage and payment rates from Kenneth Nelson et al.â€™s Social Insurance Entitlements dataset.

Â 

Colonial empire timelines. The Colonial Dates Dataset, compiled by political scientist Bastian Becker, â€œaggregates information on the reach and duration of European colonial empires from renowned secondary sources.â€ Producing the dataset from its four main sources â€œis largely automated, relying on predefined coding rules.â€ The dataset indicates the first and last years each contemporary country was colonized, disaggregated by eight colonizing countries (Belgium, Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Portugal, and Spain). [h/t Erik Gahner Larsen]

Â 

Things flung spaceward. The UNâ€™s Office for Outer Space Affairs maintains an Online Index of Objects Launched into Outer Space, based on a similarly-named register, itself mandated by a similarly-named convention, which went into force in 1976. Presented as an HTML table, the index lists 17,000+ satellites, spacecraft, probes, and other objectsâ€™ names, launching countries, statuses, launch dates, and more. As seen in: Our World In Dataâ€™s chart of the annual number of objects launched. [h/t Chartr]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send rocket-fueled feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Support the newsletter and your career by becoming a DIP+ member.
entry.summary: Opioid settlement payouts, groundwater wells, work-injury laws, colonial empire timelines, and objects launched into outer space.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.04.03 edition
entry.content:
Power outages, European Parliament activity, candid animals, LLM data provenance, and deaths in plague-era London.

Â 

ğŸ”„ Earlier this year, the USDA released the 2022 edition of its Census of Agriculture, initially featured in DIP 2015.12.23. National, state, and county data are available to download. Data for Puerto Rico are coming in July, and for the rest of US territories in 2025. [h/t Jasmine Mithani]

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ DIP+ members got a sneak peek of this editionâ€™s datasets on Monday, plus pointers to a few extra. Support the newsletter and your career by becoming a member.

Â 

Power outages. Christa Brelsford et al. have compiled a county-level estimates of the number of US customers experiencing power outages at 15-minute intervals from 2014 to 2023. The records come from Oak Ridge National Laboratoryâ€™s restricted-access Environment for Analysis of Geo-Located Energy Information, a â€œplatform created to monitor electric utility customer outages from data gathered from public sources.â€ The dataâ€™s coverage has increased over time; by 2022, it represented 92% of customers in the 50 states, DC, and Puerto Rico. â€œThe remaining 8% of customers belong to utilities which do not report outage information publicly in near-real time in a format that is currently accessible to EAGLE-I parsers,â€ the authors write. â€œThese are most typically small, rural, municipal utilities which lack robust information technology infrastructure.â€

Â 

European Parliament activity. Parltrack keeps tabs on 4,000+ active and prior members of the European Parliament, 23,000+ policy dossiers, 39,000+ votes, and much more. The project, launched in 2011, scrapes data from various official websites and links it together â€” so that you can see, for example, any given memberâ€™s dossiers, committee roles, and activities such as plenary speeches and proposed legislative amendments. Its bulk datasets are updated daily and include details beyond what the online interfaces offer. [h/t Stefan Marsiske]

Â 

Candid animals. The Labeled Information Library of Alexandria data repository is â€œintended as a resource for both machine learning (ML) researchers and those that want to harness ML for biology and conservation.â€ Its datasets include millions of images, mostly captured by motion-triggered cameras. Its North American Camera Trap Images dataset, for instance, â€œcontains 3.7M camera trap images from five locations across the United States, with labels for 28 animal categories, primarily at the species level.â€ Read more: â€œMachine learning to classify animal species in camera trap images: Applications in ecology.â€ [h/t Corin Faife]

Â 

LLM data provenance. The Data Provenance Initiative â€œis a multi-disciplinary volunteer effort to improve transparency, documentation, and responsible use of training datasets for AI.â€ Its first release, the Data Provenance Collection, catalogs dozens of corpora used for fine-tuning large language models, as well as their component datasetsâ€™ names, task categories, known sources, licensing, various text metrics, and more. Related: Yang Liu et al.â€™s â€œDatasets for Large Language Models: A Comprehensive Survey,â€ accompanied by semi-structured descriptions of hundreds of training and evaluation datasets. [h/t u/cavedave]

Â 

Deaths in plague-era London. Death by Numbers, also known as the Bills of Mortality Project, aims to transcribe ~8,000 official weekly tallies of deaths in London published in the 1600s and 1700s. Initially focused on plague deaths, the reports expanded to â€œdozens of other causes of death, such as childbirth, measles, syphilis, and suicide, ensuring their continued publication for decades after the final outbreak of plague in England.â€ The projectâ€™s data are available to browse online, to download, and via API. [h/t Derek M. Jones + Cody Winchester]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send plague-less feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Support the newsletter and your career by becoming a DIP+ member.
entry.summary: Power outages, European Parliament activity, candid animals, LLM data provenance, and deaths in plague-era London.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.03.27 edition
entry.content:
Institutional investments, HDI, extrajudicial killings in Bangladesh, agri-environmental policies, and Rolling Stoneâ€™s album rankings.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ ReaderÂ Erin Wilson has built a range of visualizations and analyses based on the Netflix viewership data featured in DIP 2023.12.20 â€¦ and a video walking you through it. (Have you published something with data you found via Data Is Plural?Â Click here to let me know.)

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ DIP+ members got a sneak peek of this editionâ€™s datasets on Monday. Support the newsletter and your career by becoming a member.

Â 

Institutional investments. If youâ€™re an institutional investor with US operations and managing at least $100 million in publicly traded securities, the Securities and Exchange Commission requires you to file Form 13F each quarter. (The biggest filers â€” such as Vanguard, BlackRock, and State Street â€” have trillions of dollars invested.) These filings, available to download going back to mid-2013, detail each investorâ€™s long positions for each security: their number of shares, market value, security type, issuer name, CUSIP code, and more. As seen in: Michigan teenager Anonyo Noorâ€™s wallstreetlocal.com, which aggregates the data, matches it to additional information, and provides a search interface.

Â 

Human development, indexed. Perhaps the best-known metric of its kind, the United Nationsâ€™ Human Development Index combines statistics on life expectancy, income per capita, and years of schooling into a single number for each country-year. The UN provides downloads and an API for all annual HDI ratings and sub-components for 1990 to 2022. Those resources also feature data from related indices, such as the Inequality-adjusted Human Development Index, Gender Development Index, and Gender Inequality Index. [h/t Michael A. Rice]

Â 

Extrajudicial killings in Bangladesh. Between 2009 and 2022, â€œBangladeshâ€™s security forces killed at least 2,597 people in apparent extrajudicial executions, custodial torture, and by firing bullets at protesters,â€ according to Nazmul Ahasanâ€™s analysis for Netra News, building on data â€œcompiled by Bangladeshi human rights defenders and collated by the Australia-based Capital Punishment Justice Project.â€ Ahasan and colleagues â€œindependently verified more than 98% of the cases in the dataset using press reports and subsequently updated any incomplete data.â€ The records are available as a table in the article and as a JSON file. Each entry includes the victimâ€™s name (if known), incident date, description, location, agencies involved, purported justification, and news source. As seen in: The 2024 Sigma Awards.

Â 

Agri-environmental policies. David Wuepper et al. have constructed a dataset of 6,000+ policies between 1960 and 2022 â€œat the intersection of agriculture and the environment, implemented not only by national entities but also by subnational and supranational entities, covering different instruments (for example, regulations, frameworks, payment programmes) and topics,â€ such as the US Safe Drinking Water Act, the Bavarian Forestry Law, and Tanzaniaâ€™s 2009 Wildlife Conservation Act. Each entry lists the policyâ€™s country, title, type, keywords, year implemented, description, and other details.

Â 

Rolling Stoneâ€™s album rankings. A new visual essay from The Pudding compares Rolling Stoneâ€™s â€œ500 Greatest Albums of All Timeâ€ lists from 2003, 2012, and 2020. A methodology note says the project began with a spreadsheet by Chris Eckert and eventually led the authors to develop a dataset of their own. Theirs lists every album in the rankings â€” its name, genre, release year, 2003/2012/2020 rank, the artistâ€™s name, birth year, gender, and more â€” plus each yearâ€™s voters. [h/t Jason Kottke]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send your greatest feedback of all time to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Support the newsletter and your career by becoming a DIP+ member.
entry.summary: Institutional investments, HDI, extrajudicial killings in Bangladesh, agri-environmental policies, and Rolling Stoneâ€™s album rankings.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.03.20 edition
entry.content:
Human trafficking, real-world vehicle emissions, state legislators, Meta Oversight Board decisions, and aviation waypoints.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Aditya Dahiya has built a showcase of his Data Is Pluralâ€“inspired visualizations. â€œHere, youâ€™ll find open-source code detailing every step, from data acquisition to final rendering,â€ Aditya writes. (Have you published something with data you found via Data Is Plural?Â Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Human trafficking. The Counter-Trafficking Data Collaborativeâ€™s Global Synthetic Dataset uses differential privacy techniques to represent â€œover 206,000 victims and survivors of trafficking identified across 190 countries and territories from 2002 to 2022.â€ The approach, developed in partnership with Microsoft Research, converts anonymized case records into â€œa new dataset in which records do not correspond to actual individuals, but which preserves the structure and statistics (i.e., utility) of the original data.â€ Each row indicates a (synthetic) individualâ€™s gender, age group, citizenship, country of exploitation, duration of reported trafficking, traffickersâ€™ means of control, types of exploitation, and the year the collaborativeâ€™s partners registered the case. Related: The collaborativeâ€™s Global Victim-Perpetrator Synthetic Dataset, which takes a similar approach to relationships between victims and perpetrators. [h/t Mariana Moreira + Lorraine Wong]

Â 

Real-world vehicle emissions. On Monday, the European Commission published its first report analyzing the real-world CO2 emissions of cars and vans, based on fuel consumption monitoring devices that the EU now requires. The report uses data received from 600,000+ vehicles. That sample is available to download, along with metrics aggregated by manufacturer and fuel type: average fuel consumption, emissions, and comparisons to standardized test results. Related: Data on millions of EU car registrations (and van registrations), including each vehicleâ€™s fuel economy and emissions ratings. Previously: FuelEconomy.gov (DIP 2017.04.12), with data on decades of car models. [h/t Jan Willem Tulp + Xan Gregg]

Â 

State legislators. Nicholas Carnes and Eric Hansenâ€™s 2023-4 State Legislators Dataset features â€œbiographical information about state lawmakers who held office in 2023 and 2024 compiled from legislative and campaign websites and other online sources.â€ The dataset spans all 50 states and includes 7,300+ lawmakers. â€œThe projectâ€™s principal aim was to record the current or most recent main occupation (outside of elected office) held by each member,â€ the authors write, â€œbut the dataset also includes information about a wide range of characteristics including race, gender, and education.â€ A version for 2021â€“22 is also available. Previously: State legislator financial disclosures (DIP 2017.12.13) and ideology scores (DIP 2020.01.01). [h/t Derek Willis]

Â 

Meta Oversight Board decisions. Metaâ€™s independent Oversight Board reviews a selection of the companyâ€™s content-moderation decisions and has the power to overturn them. The board publishes its rulings online, as does Meta itself; neither, however, provides a download link. But Information Is Beautiful has compiled a spreadsheet of the boardâ€™s 80+ decisions through early February, supporting a visualization of the casesâ€™ topics and outcomes over time. [h/t Data Science Community Newsletter]

Â 

Aviation waypoints. For his recent exploration of the FAAâ€™s aviation maps, Beautiful Public Dataâ€™s Jon Keegan has turned the agencyâ€™s list of 67,000+ navigation waypoints into a downloadable dataset. â€œOften these waypoint names will reflect the culture, food or sports teams of the city they are near,â€ Keegan writes. â€œOff the coast of New England, there is LBSTA and WHALE. Bostonâ€™s sports legacy gave us BOSOX, BRUWN, CELTS, PATSS, FENWY, ORRRR and BORQE. Salem has WITCH, and Plymouth has PLGRM.â€

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send five-lettered feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Support the newsletter and your career by becoming a DIP+ member.
entry.summary: Human trafficking, real-world vehicle emissions, state legislators, Meta Oversight Board decisions, and aviation waypoints.
